Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Secure and Privacy-Preserving Cyber Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds a new REU site at Tennessee Technological University focused on security of cyber-physical systems. Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are engineered systems that are built from, and depend upon, the seamless integration of computational algorithms and physical components. New CPS technology will transform the way people interact with engineered systems that often are fundamental to daily lives including transportation, energy, healthcare, manufacturing, building design, and many other areas critical to our society. It is vital that these systems operate and interact with people seamlessly and that they are secure and privacy-preserving. The REU site will provide undergraduates the opportunity to work during the summer with faculty mentors in state-of-the-art research labs on projects that are compelling and important to all of us. The Division of Graduate Education CyberCorps (R) Scholarship for Service Program is co-funding this project.

The project is led by an outstanding team offering modern facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of problems related to developing secure cyber-physical systems. Students will learn how to use current tools and techniques to solve those problems that have direct impact on people and the quality of daily life. The team will use proven strategies to recruit undergraduate students from groups traditionally under-represented in computer science. The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer science and engineering, recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing fields, and increasing recruitment of students into graduate programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes that we obtain to achieve the goals of our REU site are as follows:

1. One of our goals was to engage undergraduate students with various research topics related to the security and privacy of cyber-physical systems (CPS): To achieve this goal, our  REU participants worked on different technical topics. Some of these topics are as follows:

  • REU participants investigated securing the hardware of CPS by studying the side channel analysis of AES encryption against hardware Trojan
  • Security of PLC for industrial control systems is of paramount importance for modern industry, REU particpants studied the vulnerability of PLC language using formal verification techniques.
  • Self-driving cars are already been piloted in some countries and states. REU participants studied secure and privacy-preserving schemes for organizing shared rides for self-driving cars.
  • With the advent of digital home assistant and smart grid technolgies, home area network (HAN) is an important constituent of Internet of Things (IoT). Our REU participants studied security of IoT-based HAN and its vulnerability against cyber-attacks at both network and hardware levels. They also worked on cognitive health prediction on the elderly using sensor data in smart homes.
  • Electrical Vehicles (EVs) and Vehicular Ad hoc Networks (VANETs) are gaining popularity, and hence, dynamic charging for EVs (charging while in motion) is inevitable to make EVs practical and more convenient. REU students studied priority-based and privacy-preserving EV dynamic charging system. Another group of REU participants researched novel trajectory-based scheme to thwart sybil attacks in VANETs. In these attacks, attackers misuse the anonymity provided to presreve location privacy and pretend as multiple fake vehicles and send false data.
  • Cybernetwork is always under tremendous threat, in another research work REU participants researched in detecting the onset of a network layer denial of service (DoS) Attack with a Graph-Based Approach
  • Some other areas of research that REU participated worked on was Blockchain-based firmware for autonomous vehicles, testbed for  privacy-preserving automated metering infrastructure (AMI), information leakage detection in IoT, intrusion detection in an industrial control system, and security and privacy preservation of 3D printing.

2. Another goal of our REU site was to train students in state-of-the-art research topics related to CPS, including security of smart power grids, security and privacy of vehicular ad hoc network, security of IoT, and hardware security of embedded systems. The research topics listed in outcome 1 also helped these REU participants to get hands on training on all these topics. All these students helped their mentors in establishing testbed, writing codes and debugging complex systems. Under the guidance of experts in these subjects, the REU participants gained tremendous experience in these domains.

 

3. Third goal of our REU site was to promote STEM related research into the nation?s undergraduate students. In order to achieve this goal, we recruited 30 undergraduate students using a rigorous nation-wide search. Minorities and women in engineering were encouraged to apply and we were successful in recruiting excellent group of students that included 36.67% female students, 16.67 % students from minority and 23.3 % students from STEM-limited institutions.

 

4. One more goal of the REU site was to enhance the professional skills of REU participants to better articulate their research activities. We got very encouraging results to fulfil this goal as well.

a. From the projects of our REU site, the participants were able to publish 14 peer-reviewed international journal and conference papers. Moreover, 11 non-peer-reviewed technical reports and 3 different testbeds.

b. At least three of the REU students have joined graduate schools to pursue studies in the cybersecurity or other STEM related fields.

c. There are several students who are inspired by the REU program and they are pursuing a career that is related to CISE-CNS related areas. Some of the prominent cases are listed below:

  • William Johnson has graduated from the program and joined PhD program at Tennessee Tech University. Mr. Johnson is doing his PhD in cybersecurity of CPS.
  • Kameron Wells has successfully finished his undergraduate education, and has joined MS Program in University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.
  • Jacob Moran is working as a Weapon Systems Analyst (Computer Engineer) at  Dynetics, Inc. Jacob plans to attend  University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH) from Fall 2019 for his MS degree
  • Nyomor-Da Tackie-Yarboi who participated from Hostos community college, NY, has worked in IoT Intel for Intel Developer Program, at Intel Inc. He plans to attend the graduate school after graduation in 2020.
  • Many REU participants helped in writing research papers. Among them Sam Kotler and Cyd Marie Rivera Rodriguez are planning to attend graduate school.
  • Alhad Daftardar from Georgia Tech University, is working as a student research assistant in Institute for Electronics and Nanotechnology at Georgia Tech University. Alhad is planning to do his graduate studies after graduation.
